awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Super-Alfvenic propagation of energy released during magnetic reconnection in the Earth's magnetotail
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic reconnection plays a fundamental role in magnetotail dynamics, reconfiguring magnetic topology to release stored magnetic energy. The nature of the energy propagating away from the reconnection site has implications for our understanding of transient magnetotail phenomena such as bursty bulk flows, dipolarization fronts and substorms. While bulk ion flows accelerated by reconnection have been measured directly by spacecraft and have been linked to the generation of aurora the propagation speed of this energy is limited to the Alfvén speed and there is evidence that energy must propagate faster than the Alfvén speed to account for substorm onset. Less well understood, however, are super-Alfvénic flows of energy associated with kinetic electron dynamics which tend to occur near the magnetic separatrices. The quadrupolar magnetic fields in this region associated with Hall dynamics have been shown to be the manifestation of a kinetic Alfvén wave (KAW) that propagates super-Alfvénically parallel to the magnetic field and generates substantial Poynting flux associated with energetic electron streams. 

This investigation will study the basic physics mechanisms controlling the super-Alfvénic propagation of reconnection energy with focus roughly on the mid-tail region. The study will use kinetic particle-in-cell simulations (PIC) and satellite observations of reconnection from the Cluster and THEMIS spacecraft. 

This should be a significant step towards understanding the causal relationships between reconnection onset and transient magnetotail phenomena such as bursty bulk flows, dipolarization fronts, and substorm onset. However the potential benefit of this research extends beyond magnetotail research because propagation of reconnection energy is an important problem for a wide range of natural plasmas and laboratory plasmas.

por.por_cntn:
Magnetic reconnection is a process in which magnetic fields pointed in opposite directions annihilate and produce high speed flows and high energy plasma particles, including ions and electrons. In the magnetotail of the Earth magnetic reconnection drives flow bursts that can penetrate into the inner magnetosphere to provide the free energy necessary to drive the relativistic electrons of the outer radiation belt. These high-energy electrons are a threat to  Earth-circling satellties. Thus, understanding how magnetic reconnection takes place in the magnetotail is both a topic of great scientific importance and has relevance for understanding space weather and its threat to our space-based technological infrastructure.

The scientific goals of this project are to understand the structure of magnetotail flow bursts and to identify signatures that can be used to diagnose the onset and development of these events remotely. A proposed signature of the onset of magnetic reconnection in the magnetotail is the kinetic Alfven wave, which is a very fast propagating wave that is produced in the region where the magnetic fields reconnect (around 20-30 Earth-radii down the tail) and carries energy that can potentially light up the auroral region. An important scientific question is whether these waves can propagate the entire distance from their source in the tail to the auroral region and therefore act as signatures for reconnection onset. Additional goals of the project are to determine the structure of reconnection-driven flow bursts, including the development of an understanding of how the released magnetic energy energizes electrons and ions.

The significant research accomplishments from this project are as follows:

(1) Kinetic Alfven waves carry significant energy away from the site of reconnection in the Earth's magnetotail and are able to propagate without significant damping into the auroral region. These waves are therefore an important energy transport mechanism and can serve as indicators of reconnection onset. These waves, however, are not able of propagating far enough during flare onset in the solar corona to significantly influence energy transport in flares.

(2) The relative heating of electrons and ions during magnetic reconnection is controlled by a large-scale electric potential that develops within the reconnection exhaust. This potential serves to confine heated electrons within the exhaust and prevent their escape along the magnetic field into the upstream region. Thus, a higher potential leads to more energy going into electrons. In contrast, the potential acts to repell ions entering into the reconnection exhaust and therefore reduces their energy gain. The overall amplitude of the potential is controlled by the ambient, upstream electron temperature -- high upstream electron temperature leads to a larger potential and stronger electron heating. Thus, energy partition in the magnetosphere where ions gain more energy than electrons from reconnection is not universal but is a consequence of the ambient electrons in the magnetosphere having lower temperature than ions.

(3) Reconnect drives strong bulk flows of plasma in the magnetotail. Satellite observations have revealed that leading edges of these flow bursts are sharp and propagate long distances with no significant broadening. They are not shocks so their structure and role in the conversion of magnetic-to-particle energy was unknown. We have shown that the jet fronts are sites where the bulk flow driven by reconnection is dissipated. Ions ahead of the front reflect off of the front and in doing so gain significant energy. This causes the front to slow so that the flow burst piles up at the front and is deflected in the cross-tail direction. Thus, the reconnetion fronts in the tail reveal an entirely new mechanism for the dissipation of bulk flow energy that differs from the classic shock mechanism that has been widely explored in the past.

Graduate students and early-career scientists have played key roles in the research efforts under this grant. The research effort has therefore contributed to the production of a technologically able workforce, an important goal of the scientific enterprise supported by the Federal Govenment.
